title: Charles van den Heuvel, A classification of the arts in a digital ecosystem. Exploring Dynamic ODP’s
text:
Charles van den Heuvel studied Art History at the University of Groningen and gained his PhD in 1991 with a thesis on the introduction of Italian urban planning and fortification in the Netherlands (1540-1609). After his study he worked in various cultural heritage institutions, universities and research institutions.

From January 2011 till December 2022, Van den Heuvel was head of the research group of history of knowledge, now known as Knowledge and Art Practices. Furthermore, he is an emeritus professor at the University of Amsterdam holding the chair: “Digital Methods and Historical Disciplines, especially the History of Knowledge and Information Science”. He was the p.i. of the following projects:

  • NWO Large Investment Grant: Golden Agents: Creative Industries and the Making of the Dutch Golden Age. (2017-2022)
  • NWO Smart Culture – Big Data/Digital Humanities: Virtual Interiors as Interfaces for Big Historical Data (2018-2022)
  • NWO/NWA science communication [only in Dutch]: Door de lens van Antoni/[Through the lens of Antoni] (2022)
  • KNAW Public-Private Cooperation-Digital Humanities: Mapping Notes and Nodes in Networks: Exploring potential relationships in biographical data and cultural networks in the creative industry in Amsterdam and Rome in the Early Modern Period (2014)
  • KNAW Public-Private Cooperation-Digital Humanities: Dynamic Drawings in Enhanced Publications (2012-2013)

Furthermore, he was the co-applicant and leader on behalf of the Huygens Institute in the consortium of the NWO- Middle Large Investment project:

  • Circulation of Knowledge and Learned Practices in the 17th Century Dutch Republic/ePistolarium

Since his retirement in December 2022, he is a guest employee at the Huygens Institute, a research institute of the "Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences (KNAW)" in Amsterdam,  and in particular he works in the departments Data Management and Knowledge & Art Practices in which context he will continue his research directed toward the application of digital resources and methods in the Humanities.

subtitle: Lecture conducted as part of the Cultural Heritage in the Digital Ecosystem PhD programme

title: Patrimonio culturale e infrastrutture di ricerca: la conservazione e la comunicazione al pubblico
text:
Building on the experience of the European project (H2020) Una.Resin, where methodologies and tools for creating research and innovation ecosystems in transnational research networks were developed, the aim is to analyze the impact of digital transformation and the interconnection of data and interdependent ecosystems on the preservation and communication of cultural heritage.

The inquiry will explore how digital research infrastructures interact with cultural heritage, as well as with the data aggregations and digital assets of libraries, archives, and museums. The scope extends beyond the materials of university libraries and museums, delving into the galaxy of research initiatives and materials preserved by both university and non-university institutions made available through specific thematic/disciplinary projects.

The purpose of this reflection is to initiate a dialogue on forms of cultural heritage sharing that are compatible and interoperable with research infrastructures, fostering fruitful exchanges between cultural institutions and heritage communities with scientific research institutions. This transition into digital infrastructures carries with it a complex experience and activity of integrating semantic relationships from diverse scientific and educational fields preceding the digital era.

Discussions will revolve around how universities can facilitate the valorization of cultural heritage through digital research infrastructures, not only limited to their own heritage but also stimulating interoperability with other local and international initiatives. It will encourage synergies on common interests such as long-term preservation, innovative forms of participation, citizen science, storytelling, open licenses, etc.

Further reflections will focus on the flexibility of conceptual models for integrating content and metadata, ensuring the potential for interaction with digital research infrastructures structured internationally across various disciplinary domains. This includes the development of new ways to share delivery data and the provision of services, especially in Knowledge Discovery.
